A law of composition on a set $M$ is said to be associative if $(ab)c = a(bc)$ for all elements $a, b, c \in M$.

An element $d \in R$ is called a greatest common divisor of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $d \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $d$ is a common divisor of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common divisor of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $a \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $a \mid d$.
Does the concept of a/an Associative Law need to be defined for a definition of a/an Greatest common divisor to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of the Greatest Common Divisor (GCD) involves determining a divisor that is common to all elements in a set and that any other common divisor of these elements must also divide this GCD. This definition focuses on divisibility and the relationship between divisors and elements in a ring or set, without requiring any specific operation to be associative.

The Associative Law, on the other hand, pertains to the property of an operation (like addition or multiplication) being associative within a set. This law ensures that the grouping of operations does not affect the outcome.

In the definition of GCD, there is no direct or implied need for the operation (like addition or multiplication) to be associative. The GCD concept is primarily concerned with divisibility and does not depend on the associative property of operations. Therefore, the Associative Law does not need to be defined or assumed for the definition of the GCD to make sense.
